DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft to hold worldwide conference in L.A.

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp. has chosen Los Angeles as the venue for its Worldwide Partner Conference (WPC) next year, which will bring between 12,000 and 15,000 people, Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa announced on Monday.
The gathering will be held at the Los Angeles Convention Center on July 10-14 next year, the mayor said.
The conference, one of the biggest events to be held at the center, is expected to generate about 45 million dollars in spending, according to the mayor's office.
"Hosting this banner event for the global technology community is a major win for Los Angeles and an important boost for our local economy," Villaraigosa said.
The mayor was touting Microsoft's decision to hold the conference in the city as evidence that downtown Los Angeles is much safer, cleaner and more exciting than it was years ago.
"We look forward to welcoming Microsoft and its partners to L.A. next summer," he said, "and showing them the best of what this world-class city has to offer."
The conference will bring together "worldwide business partners who sell, customize, build upon, implement and support Microsoft solutions," the mayor's office said.

"L.A. is a dynamic, exciting city that inspires creativity and innovation," Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer said. "It's an ideal setting for our global community of 15,000 partners from 120 countries to share their ideas and energy for technology and business opportunities in the years ahead."
"We look forward to furthering our long, rewarding relationship with the city and community and are sure our partners and employees will make the most of their time in L.A.," Ballmer said.
According to the mayor's office, nearly 95 percent of Microsoft 's 60 billion dollars in total annual revenue is generated by its worldwide partner network.
Mark Liberman, president of L.A. Inc., the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the Microsoft 2011 WPC will be the largest citywide convention in the history of Los Angeles.
"This meeting underscores L.A.'s new reputation as a vibrant destination by the meetings industry, sparked by the addition of the L.A. Live campus," he said.
